diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, usually a reaction to a medication or an infection.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute, febrile illness of childhood that affects the blood vessels and can cause coronary artery aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening skin disorder characterized by widespread erythema, necrosis, and bullous detachment of the epidermis and mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
diagnoses.description: A severe, drug-induced reaction that involves the skin and internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

diagnoses.name: Measles

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick, characterized by a sudden onset of fever and headache, followed by a rash.

diagnoses.name: Mycoplasma Pneumonia
diagnoses.description: An infection of the lungs caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, often resulting in pneumonia and characterized by symptoms such as fever, cough, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease resulting from a group A streptococcus infection, known for its striking red rash.

diagnoses.name: Measles (Rubeola)
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection that's known for its distinctive rash and fever. It can lead to serious complications.

diagnoses.name: Rubella (German Measles)
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. Though generally mild in children, it can cause serious birth defects if a woman is infected during pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild viral illness causing a slap cheek rash in children, but might cause joint pain and swelling in adults.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Often associated with tampon use but not exclusively.

diagnoses.name: Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by infection with certain strains of Staphylococcus bacteria. It affects the skin, causing it to blister and look as though it has been scalded.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body parts, including the skin, joints, heart, lungs, blood, kidneys, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, abdominal pain, and kidney problems. It's most common in children.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites, characterized by a rash, fever, and headache. It can be serious if not treated promptly with antibiotics.

diagnoses.description: Usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, infectious mononucleosis, or mono, can lead to symptoms such as fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that primarily affects children under the age of 5 and is characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels throughout the body. Symptoms may include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, red eyes, lips, and throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can cause a sore, scratchy throat, redness in the oropharynx, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. It's most commonly caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus infection
diagnoses.description: A virus that can cause a range of illnesses including cold-like symptoms, sore throat, bronchitis, pneumonia, diarrhea, and pink eye (conjunctivitis).

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) attacks the immune system and weakens your ability to fight infections and disease. AIDS is the stage of infection that occurs when your immune system is badly damaged and you become vulnerable to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a spreading rash. It may also cause complications like pneumonia and encephalitis.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: Also known as German measles, rubella is a contagious disease caused by a virus. Its symptoms include rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal increase in white blood cells. Symptoms may include fatigue, fever, an increased risk of infections, and enlarged lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. It can cause flu-like symptoms, including swollen lymph nodes and muscle aches and pains that may last from a few days to several weeks.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with arthropathy, malar (or butterfly) rash, and can go on to affect systemic organs causing seizures (neurological involvement) and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While less common, rheumatoid arthritis can manifest with systemic symptoms beyond arthropathy, including dermatological and cardiac manifestations; however, seizures are not typically associated.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus Tumidus
diagnoses.rationale: This less common form of cutaneous lupus erythematosus can present with skin signs like malar rash and dyspigmentation without systemic involvement; seizures and pericarditis would be rare.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash which can include dyspigmentation. More common in children, seizures and other systemic manifestations can occur.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder shares features with systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. It can present with arthropathy, rash, and have neurological and cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem inflammatory disease that can present with arthropathy, skin manifestations like lupus pernio (which may resemble malar rash), and potentially affect the nervous system causing seizures and pericardium leading to acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can cause arthritis, skin rash, and neurological symptoms (including seizures), but acute pericarditis would be less common.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can coexist with or mimic many features of systemic lupus erythematosus, including potential for seizures, cardiac involvement, and skin manifestations; however, a direct association with malar rash is less typical.

diagnoses.name: Neuro-Sweet’s Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This rare condition can manifest with arthropathy, dyspigmentation (often in the form of sterile pustules), and CNS involvement which might include seizures. Cardiac involvement like pericarditis is less common.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause a constellation of symptoms including rash, seizures (due to encephalitis), joint pain (arthropathy), and less commonly, acute pericarditis. Examples include Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral, Bacterial, or Tuberculosis infections causing pericarditis and secondary autoimmune responses)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia plus Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with nephritis, acute pericarditis, arthropathy, and can also manifest skin changes resembling follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing arthropathy, rheumatoid arthritis can sometimes lead to pericarditis and, more rarely, nephritis as part of its extra-articular manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This is an inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash (which could involve follicular hyperkeratosis) and muscle weakness but can also involve the joints and has been associated with pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders — including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, with patients presenting with arthropathy, nephritis, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the skin and connective tissue, scleroderma can cause renal crisis (nephritis), arthralgia or arthropathy, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, it might include follicular hyperkeratosis among its skin manifestations, along with arthropathy and less commonly pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV can indirectly cause nephritis through HIV-associated nephropathy, affect skin texture causing follicular hyperkeratosis, and lead to pericarditis and arthropathy due to opportunistic infections or direct effects of the virus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, it can lead to Lyme nephritis, Lyme arthritis, potential skin manifestations, and in some cases, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Viral Hepatitis
diagnoses.rationale: Some forms of viral hepatitis can lead to extrahepatic manifestations including arthropathy and rarely pericarditis. Hepatitis C, for example, can be associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia that can present with a rash resembling follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the heart valves, if left untreated, it can spread and cause pericarditis. It can also cause arthritic symptoms, and in rare cases, can be associated with skin manifestations and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which excessive numbers of mast cells are activated, leading to severe allergic symptoms including muscle pain, dermatographism, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune response to a substance that most people tolerate well; symptoms may include dermatographism, hypersensitivity reactions, and possibly muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues; might lead to symptoms including muscle pain and dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that results in recurrent attacks of swelling in various parts of the body including the extremities, face, gastrointestinal tract, and airways; it can be associated with hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, leading to a wide range of symptoms including muscle pain and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Symptoms may include muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen, symptoms may include hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears, leading to dry mouth (oral pain) among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Allergies
diagnoses.description: Having multiple allergies can lead to a variety of symptoms including dermatographism, hypersensitivity reactions, and possibly oral pain due to allergic reactions affecting the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where hives and swelling occur without a known cause, symptoms can include dermatographism and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses: Secondary hypertension due to another disease
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Systemic lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Wilson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Symptoms can include liver disease, neurological symptoms, and psychiatric problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause muscle spasms, difficulty in coordination and balance, pain, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Neurodegenerative disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders, characterized by the progressive degeneration of the structure and function of the nervous system. These disorders might present a wide range of symptoms including muscle pain, seizures, and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Symptoms start gradually, sometimes starting with a barely noticeable tremor in just one hand. It also causes stiffness and slowing of movement.

diagnoses.name: Huntington's Disease
diagnoses.description: A progressive brain disorder caused by a defective gene. This disease causes changes in the central area of the brain, which affect movement, mood, and thinking skills.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages. Over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Dystonia
diagnoses.description: A neurological movement disorder characterized by sustained muscle contractions, causing repetitive movements or abnormal postures. It can be focal or generalized, and its symptoms could include blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet. It can also affect other areas of your body.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of conditions that affect the ability to sleep well on a regular basis. These disorders can be due to a health problem or too much stress. Sleep problems are often linked to neurological disorders as well.

diagnoses.reasoning: GERD can cause symptoms such as dyspepsia and wheezing due to the aspiration of gastric contents.
Wheezing is a hallmark symptom of asthma, which might also contribute to frequent waking.
Anxiety can contribute to attention deficit, dyspepsia, and frequent waking due to heightened stress levels.
Sleep disorders can lead to symptoms such as frequent waking and attention deficit due to disturbed sleep patterns.
This is a common cause of vaginitis and can co-occur with unrelated symptoms if the overall health is compromised or if there are other risk factors.
Candidiasis is a fungal infection causing vaginitis and might present in individuals with compromised immune systems, potentially exacerbating other health issues.
Allergic rhinitis can cause symptoms like wheezing and may be associated with disturbed sleep due to congestion, leading to frequent waking.
ADHD is characterized by attention deficit and could contribute to difficulties in maintaining sleep hygiene, potentially explaining frequent waking.
Peptic ulcer disease can cause dyspepsia. Less directly associated with the other symptoms but could coexist as part of a broader symptomatology.
COPD can cause wheezing and may disrupt sleep due to difficulty breathing, indirectly related to symptoms like frequent waking.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the middle ear, leading to pain and potential hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by uncontrollable, recurring thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions) that the individual feels the urge to repeat.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear.

diagnoses.name: Dental Abscess
diagnoses.description: A localized bacterial infection at the root of a tooth or in between the gum and a tooth.

diagnoses.name: Thyrotoxicosis
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by an excess of thyroid hormones, which can lead to a variety of symptoms including palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Acute Laryngitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the larynx, usually caused by a viral infection leading to voice changes such as hoarseness.

diagnoses.name: Tonsillitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the tonsils, which can cause throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and potentially ear pain due to referred pain.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach acid comes back into the esophagus, sometimes leading to throat discomfort or pain.

diagnoses.name: General Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic syndrome characterized by excessive, long-lasting anxiety and worry about nonspecific life events, objects, and situations.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.description: A psychiatric disorder characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Thyroid Disorders (such as Graves' disease or Hashimoto's thyroiditis)

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like malabsorption and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can cause inflammation anywhere along the digestive tract, leading to symptoms like ulcers, lymphadenopathy, and malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, presenting with symptoms like ulcers in the mouth and genitals (potentially explaining vulvodynia), and can impact the digestive system as well.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system and can cause lymphadenopathy. Patients may experience malabsorption, increased appetite, ulcers, and other symptoms as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to lymph nodes and other parts of the body, causing lymphadenopathy and ulcers in various organs.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy. It can also affect the body's ability to absorb nutrients, resulting in malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands, causing lymphadenopathy. It can also lead to malabsorption and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection that can cause lymphadenopathy and ulcers, including genital ulcers that could be associated with vulvodynia in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage throughout the body, potentially leading to lymphadenopathy, ulcers, and malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A condition with symptoms similar to those of celiac disease, such as malabsorption and abdominal pain, but without the autoimmune response to gluten.

diagnoses: Kidney failure or chronic kidney disease

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently high eosinophil count in the blood, leading to organ damage. It can cause various symptoms, including easy bleeding and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this is a type of vasculitis that can lead to eosinophilia, leukocytosis, and systemic issues that may explain difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause atherosclerosis and affect organ systems, potentially leading to eosinophilia and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the white blood cells leading to leukocytosis, and in some cases, can cause eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
diagnoses.description: A fast-growing form of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that can cause leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and bleeding issues.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic Infections
diagnoses.description: Certain parasitic infections can lead to eosinophilia and leukocytosis. They may indirectly affect the cardiovascular system, potentially exacerbating conditions like atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease that causes the small and medium-sized arteries to become swollen and damaged. It might contribute to atherosclerosis progression and can be associated with increased eosinophil counts.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder characterized by high levels of eosinophils. It may present with symptoms such as easy bleeding and leukocytosis but does not have a known cause.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A severe reaction to medication that includes skin rash, eosinophilia, and other systemic symptoms, which might include leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body. It can cause leukocytosis, and eosinophilia, and potentially contribute to cardiovascular diseases like atherosclerosis.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Could manifest as glycemic lability. In severe cases or specific types (like type 1 diabetes), it might contribute to overall systemic symptoms such as oral pain (due to infections like thrush or gum diseases) and can affect the immune system, potentially leading to otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that make tears and saliva, causing dry mouth and eyes, which could lead to oral pain and secondary infections like otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Compromises the immune system, potentially leading to more severe instances of common infections like otitis externa, and can cause lymphadenopathy. Oral pain could signify oral thrush, a common issue in immunocompromised patients.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), lungs (dyspnea), and potentially influence glycemic control. Oral pain and otitis externa are less specific but possible manifestations depending on the extent of organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, it can cause lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and night sweats, which might indirectly cause or exacerbate other symptoms like oral pain due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and damage to various parts of the body including the skin (potentially affecting the external ear), the joints, kidneys, and more, leading to symptoms like lymphadenopathy and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA)
diagnoses.description: A disease that causes inflammation of small and medium-sized blood vessels (vasculitis), potentially leading to dyspnea and could complicate with eosinophilia which might induce varying degrees of glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-related Disease
diagnoses.description: A fibro-inflammatory condition that can lead to tumor-like swelling of involved organs, including salivary glands (potentially causing oral pain) and the ears (otitis externa), while lymphadenopathy can appear due to the systemic nature of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
diagnoses.description: A form of vasculitis that can cause granulomas and inflammation in the respiratory tract (leading to dyspnea) and other organs, which could theoretically affect the external auditory canal (otitis externa) and other structures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous symptoms, including oral ulcers (pain), possibly affecting eyes and ears, and can feature systemic symptoms like lymphadenopathy.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with widespread symptoms, including hematological disorders (e.g., leukocytosis), skin manifestations (e.g., angioedema), and musculoskeletal symptoms (e.g., bone pain). Neurological involvement could potentially manifest as cognitive dysfunctions akin to attention deficits.

Parasitic infections – Certain parasites, such as those causing schistosomiasis or strongyloidiasis, can lead to eosinophilia, diarrhea, and potentially other systemic symptoms.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome – This condition, characterized by high levels of eosinophils, can cause damage to multiple organs, including the gastrointestinal system, potentially leading to diarrhea.
Gastrointestinal disorders – Inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis could potentially present with both eosinophilia and diarrhea.
Allergic gastroenteritis – An immune response to certain foods or other substances can lead to eosinophilia and diarrhea.
Tropical sprue – This condition can cause malabsorption, diarrhea, and potentially eosinophilia in patients who have traveled to or live in tropical regions.
Celiac disease – An autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten that can cause diarrhea and possibly eosinophilia in some cases.

Churg-Strauss syndrome – Now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition can cause eosinophilia and may affect multiple organs, including the gastrointestinal tract and lungs, potentially leading to symptoms like diarrhea and pneumonia.

Asthma or allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis – While primarily respiratory conditions, they can be associated with eosinophilia and, in severe cases, could potentially correlate with pneumonia symptoms.
Immunodeficiencies – Such conditions can lead to recurrent infections like pneumonia, and depending on the underlying cause, might be associated with eosinophilia and gastrointestinal symptoms.
Drug reactions – Certain medications can induce eosinophilia, diarrhea, and more rarely, conditions such as pneumonia or symptoms mimicking postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily psychological, severe anxiety can manifest physically and could exacerbate or mimic symptoms such as muscle pain, dysphagia (due to psychological phenomena), and mediate depression.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause systemic symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and muscle pain. Depression can occur in any chronic illness. Rare cases may exhibit dysphagia if there's involvement of structures near the esophagus.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Similar reasoning as Hodgkin's, with the potential for more diffuse symptoms, including angioedema due to inflammatory responses.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Esophagitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Presents with dysphagia and could be associated indirectly with muscle pain and lymphadenopathy due to allergic reactions. Although depression is not a direct symptom, chronic pain and discomfort can lead to or exacerbate depression.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dysosmia due to dysfunction of the salivary and lacrimal glands, potentially affecting systemic organs and causing lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), eyes (leading to dry eyes and vision problems), and potentially affecting the olfactory system causing dysosmia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and nervous system, possibly resulting in symptoms like lymphadenitis and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also affect other organs, potentially leading to dry eyes (Sjögren's syndrome as a secondary condition), and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: Referring not only to a symptom but also to a condition, angioedema can be hereditary or acquired, leading to rapid edema of areas like the face, extremities, and genitals. It is associated with systemic diseases and can present with symptoms such as dysosmia.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms like lymphadenitis. It can also affect the eye area, potentially causing dry eyes and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can affect vision and possibly lead to eye dryness and other symptoms like mouth sores and genital sores, reflecting systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels, which can affect the nose (leading to dysosmia), eyes (causing vision problems and dry eyes), and lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels (most often in the head) that can lead to vision problems and systemic symptoms including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this is a condition that leads to inflammation of the blood vessels and can cause symptoms related to the eyes, lymph nodes, and potentially affect senses like smell.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, angioedema, and respiratory symptoms like nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). It may involve abdominal cramping due to intestinal wall swelling.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder wherein the adrenal glands produce insufficient hormones, leading to hypotension, abdominal pain, and other nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Nonallergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the inner part of the nose not caused by an allergy. It can cause nasal congestion and might co-occur with other non-specific systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Bladder
diagnoses.description: A urinary problem where the bladder doesn't empty properly, leading to incontinence. Can be associated with various systemic symptoms depending on the underlying cause.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by an excess of mast cells in the body. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, anaphylaxis-like symptoms, hypotension, and skin problems.

diagnoses.name: Intestinal Obstruction
diagnoses.description: A blockage that prevents the passage of food through the intestine. Can lead to severe abdominal cramps, hypotension if complicated by strangulation, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening response to an infection which can cause hypotension (shock), leading to organ failure and sometimes incontinence due to poor organ function.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include angioedema, abdominal cramps, hypotension, and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting. While typically provoked by stress or prolonged standing, it can manifest as hypotension, and in rare cases might coincidentally link with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and time-dependent goings such as headaches.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves neurological disturbances such as visual disturbances (e.g., scintillating scotomas), sensory changes, or speech difficulties before the actual headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief, temporary disruption of blood flow to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, which may cause symptoms similar to those of a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, changes in speech or vision, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include weakness and difficulty with coordination and balance.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. Viral infections are the most common cause of encephalitis, but other causes include bacterial infections and autoimmune diseases. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Aphasia and other sensory disturbances can sometimes occur depending on the part of the brain affected.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in your brain leaks or ruptures. Brain hemorrhages can result from many conditions that affect your blood vessels. Symptoms can mimic those of an ischemic stroke, including weakness and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Ischemic Stroke
diagnoses.description: An ischemic stroke occurs when a blood clot blocks a blood vessel to the brain, which can lead to brain damage and symptoms such as weakness, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. It is most often caused by a bacterial or viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the actual headache. Symptoms can include scintillation, scotoma, sensory symptoms like paresthesia, and in some cases, dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can fluctuate and include scotoma, paresthesia, dysphagia, and in some cases, headache and visual disturbances like scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents temporary symptoms resembling a stroke. Symptoms can include scotoma, scintillation, paresthesia, dysphagia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include sudden onset of headache, scintillation, scotoma, paresthesia, and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause headaches, scotoma, scintillation, paresthesia, and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by varying degrees of weakness of the voluntary muscles of the body. It can lead to symptoms such as dysphagia and in some cases, scotoma, scintillation, paresthesia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare form of ischemic stroke occurring during a migraine with aura. Symptoms include severe migraine headache, scotoma, scintillation, and possibly paresthesia and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels most commonly involving large and medium arteries of the head. Patients might experience headache, visual disturbances including scotoma and scintillation, dysphagia, and sometimes paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Moyamoya Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder caused by blocked arteries at the base of the brain. The symptoms can include headache, scotoma, scintillation, paresthesia, and in later stages, dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include visual disturbances like scotoma and scintillation, headache, dysphagia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses: Vascular Ischemic Events (Transient Ischemic Attack or Stroke)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble seeing, walking, severe headache, nausea, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura (classic migraines) are headaches that are preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs or symptoms, such as flashes of light, blind spots (scotoma), tingling in the arm or leg, nausea, and speech or language problems (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as paralysis or muscle weakness, numbness, sudden confusion, and difficulties with speech and vision. However, unlike a stroke, the symptoms of a TIA usually last less than 24 hours and then resolve completely.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, partial or complete loss of vision, prolonged double vision, and tingling or pain in parts of your body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can cause a variety of symptoms based on their location and size. Common symptoms may include headaches, seizures, numbness, nausea and vomiting, weakness or loss of sensation in the arms and legs, balance issues, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. In its most severe form Guillain-Barre syndrome is a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, nausea, vomiting, confusion or altered consciousness, and can have neurological symptoms like weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of epilepsy can also cause visual disturbances (scotoma) and temporary paralysis or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. Early symptoms may include headache, fatigue, fever, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. If untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system, potentially causing symptoms like numbness and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: Hypoglycemia refers to low blood sugar in the bloodstream. Symptoms may include weakness, seizures, nausea, hunger, confusion, and mood changes. In serious cases, if not addressed, hypoglycemia can lead to coma.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include inability to move or feel on one side of the body, problems understanding or speaking, dizziness, or loss of vision to one side.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms can include headaches, changes in personality, weakness, seizures, or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Transverse Myelitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of both sides of one section of the spinal cord. This neurological disorder often damages the insulating material covering nerve cell fibers (myelin). Transverse myelitis interrupts the messages that the spinal cord nerves send throughout the body, causing pain, muscle weakness, paralysis, sensory problems, or bladder and bowel dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. The first symptom is usually a red rash, which may look like a bull's eye. But it can lead to more serious issues like heart problems, arthritis, and neurological disorders, including symptoms like facial palsy, neuropathy, and impaired muscle movement.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck. Depending on the cause, meningitis can get better on its own, or it can be life-threatening, requiring urgent antibiotic treatment.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur if you have diabetes. High blood sugar (glucose) can injure nerves throughout your body. Diabetic neuropathy most often damages nerves in your legs and feet.

diagnoses.name: Chiari Malformation
diagnoses.description: A condition in which brain tissue extends into your spinal canal. It occurs when part of your skull is abnormally small or misshapen, pressing on your brain and forcing it downward. Chiari malformation is uncommon, but increased use of imaging tests has led to more frequent diagnoses.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of symptoms including dysphagia, weakness, ataxia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, leading to symptoms such as weakness, dysphagia, and ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by varying degrees of weakness of the skeletal (voluntary) muscles of the body, which may include symptoms such as dysphagia and generalized muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nervous system, potentially leading to weakness, ataxia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain which can cause a variety of neurological symptoms depending on its location, including weakness, dysphagia, and ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, causing muscle weakness, dysphagia, and eventually paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare neurodegenerative disorder characterized by autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and ataxia, including symptoms such as weakness and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to ataxia, paresthesia, and in advanced cases, weakness and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to neurological issues due to its role in maintaining the health of nerve cells, including symptoms such as ataxia, paresthesia, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transverse Myelitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of both sides of one section of the spinal cord, which can disrupt the messages that the spinal cord nerves send throughout the body, leading to symptoms including weakness, paresthesia, and in some cases, dysphagia.

diagnoses: Stroke (specifically in the brainstem or cerebellum regions)

diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.
Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain.

A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, commonly characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle weakness, difficulty with coordination and balance, speech problems, and visual disturbances.
A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, cognitive or personality changes, speech or vision issues, and motor problems.
A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.
A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).
A group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, which is vital to good vision. This damage is often caused by abnormally high pressure in your eye.
Low blood sugar, a condition that occurs when the level of glucose in your blood drops below the normal range. It can cause symptoms such as headache, dizziness, weakness, and visual disturbances.

A condition resulting from the reduction of blood flow to the back part of the brain, which is caused by damage or narrowing of the arteries. Symptoms can include dizziness, vision problems, slurred speech, and imbalance.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems and often presents with skin rashes, such as malar rash, hematologic abnormalities including hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and sometimes psoriaform rashes.

diagnoses.description: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory condition characterized by skin rashes and muscle weakness. It can occasionally present with features similar to systemic lupus erythematosus, including various rashes and hematological abnormalities.

diagnoses.description: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This is a lupus-like syndrome triggered by certain medications. It can cause symptoms similar to SLE, such as rashes and hematological issues.

diagnoses.description: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features elements of lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and sometimes rheumatoid arthritis, presenting with wide-ranging symptoms including rashes and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, rheumatoid arthritis can present with systemic symptoms including rheumatoid vasculitis that may lead to skin manifestations such as rashes and hematologic issues.

diagnoses.description: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases and can manifest with a variety of symptoms including rash, thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.description: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Evans Syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, potentially presenting with skin manifestations.

diagnoses.description: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing thrombocytopenia, ITP can sometimes be associated with other autoimmune symptoms including rashes.

diagnoses.description: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with skin rashes (including psoriasiform rash), thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow involvement, and anemia, including hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.description: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a wide array of symptoms including skin rashes, transient aplastic crisis leading to hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Chronic Hepatitis B or C infection
Lupus Erythematosus, Chronic Cutaneous (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus)
Lupus-like syndrome induced by certain medications
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immunologic Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
Infectious causes such as HIV or Hepatitis

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as discoid rash, arthropathy, proteinuria (indicative of kidney involvement), and can also cause pleural effusion and CNS manifestations like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing arthropathy, RA can also lead to pleural effusion and, more rarely, renal involvement manifesting as proteinuria. Skin manifestations and systemic symptoms could mimic those seen in other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease is characterized by features of several connective tissue diseases, including SLE, and can present with symptoms such as proteinuria, arthropathy, and rash. Pleural effusion and CNS involvement like delirium can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affecting the exocrine glands, it can have systemic manifestations, including arthropathy and renal involvement (proteinuria). Pleural effusion and rashes are less common but can occur. Neurological symptoms can also manifest.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease affects skin and muscles, presenting with a rash that can be discoid in nature. It may involve the lungs (pleural effusion), joints (arthropathy), and kidneys (proteinuria). Brain involvement is less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: This infection of the heart valves can cause systemic issues including rash, renal involvement (proteinuria), and can lead to embolic phenomena causing arthropathy. It can also result in pleural effusion. CNS involvement may lead to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by skin thickening, it can also involve the kidneys (proteinuria), joints (arthropathy), and cause pleural effusion. Brain involvement is uncommon but could contribute to symptoms like delirium in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This group of diseases can cause widespread systemic involvement including arthropathy, renal involvement (proteinuria), and skin rashes which can be discoid. CNS involvement and pleural effusion can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its later stages, this tick-borne illness can affect the skin (rash), joints (arthropathy), and nervous system (potentially leading to symptoms such as delirium). Kidney involvement and pleural effusion are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Following a streptococcal infection, this condition primarily affects the kidneys (proteinuria) but can also lead to rash, joint pain (arthropathy), and in rare cases, other systemic symptoms such as those affecting the lungs (pleural effusion) and CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: The combination of discoid rash, thrombocytopenia, and synovitis is highly suggestive of SLE. Lupus can present with a wide range of dermatological manifestations, including annular polycyclic rashes.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Dermatomyositis can present with similar dermatologic symptoms, including rash and could be associated with muscle weakness. It's less commonly associated with thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.reason: Given lichen planus is one of the symptoms, it must be considered. Though typically a localized skin condition, it can accompany systemic symptoms and overlap with other systemic diseases.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Synovitis is a hallmark of rheumatoid arthritis. While less common, rheumatoid arthritis can present with skin manifestations that resemble the rashes described.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD can present with features of multiple autoimmune diseases, including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. It can involve rashes, thrombocytopenia, and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: This is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Psoriatic skin lesions can sometimes mimic annular polycyclic rashes. It can also involve thrombocytopenia and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.reason: Some medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, presenting with symptoms such as rash, thrombocytopenia, and joint pain or synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Panniculitis (Lupus Profundus)
diagnoses.reason: This is a rare form of chronic cutaneous lupus presenting with deep inflammatory nodules and plaques. It can be associated with systemic lupus symptoms like those described.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: It's primarily known for causing dry mouth and dry eyes, but it's an autoimmune disorder that can also lead to extraglandular manifestations such as vasculitic rashes, arthritis, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Vasculitis can lead to skin manifestations that could be mistaken for the described rashes. It can also affect blood platelet counts and cause joint symptoms.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Felty's Syndrome
